Bash(gh issue comment 1 --body "$\(cat <<''EOF''
## Approach

**Hypothesis**: "Pigeonholing" — correlated signals across firms may produce right-skewed offer count distributions for certain groups, even under equal average offer rates. We look for evidence of this in the NYFED SCE job search supplement using `js19` \(offers received in last 4 weeks\).

**Sample restriction**: Filter to active job searchers \(responded yes to L5/L6\) or those who received at least one offer. This ensures we compare like-for-like rather than mixing searchers with non-searchers.

**Subgroup strategy**: To make apples-to-apples comparisons, we condition on observables before comparing offer distributions by gender. We first run a sample size analysis across candidate subgroup definitions \(education × gender, education × region × gender, education × industry × gender\) to determine which stratifications maintain adequate cell sizes \(n ≥ ~20–30\). This analysis will be saved as a CSV table for documentation.

**Proof-of-concept plots** \(men vs. women overlaid histograms of offer counts\):
1. Faceted by education \(rows\) × region \(columns\)
2. Faceted by education \(rows\) × industry \(columns\), with industry collapsed to ~5–6 macro sectors

**Output**: Subgroup sample size table \(CSV\) + two PDF figures saved to `/figures/`.

**Code**: Single R script at `/code/explore_nyfed.R`, tidyverse style.
EOF
